text: Step 1. Be positive
source_text: Step 1. Be positive

text: Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.
source_text: Praise your child or teenager for something they have done well. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

text: Step 2. Be specific
source_text: Step 2. Be specific

text: Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'
source_text: Praise the behaviour. Use words to describe the behaviour that you are praising. Say, 'Well done for finishing all your chores, Sam,' instead of 'Good job.'

text: Step 3. Be enthusiastic

text: Really mean it when you say it! The more real you are the better it will feel.

text: Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.
source_text: Here's a video to help you create daily routines with your children.

text: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:
source_text: Here are 4 simple tips that you can use when establishing routines with your children:

text: 1. Give one instruction at a time
source_text: 1. Give one instruction at a time

text: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one
source_text: 2. Use transition warnings to help move from one activity to the next one

text: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times
source_text: 3. Create regular eating and sleeping times

text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines
source_text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily routines

text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to 4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.
source_text: To learn more about one of these tips, type "1" to 4". You can also type "N" to stop this tip.

text: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!
source_text: 1. Help your younger children learn routines by taking them through the activity step by step. Give one instruction at a time. Praise them each time they follow!

text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!
source_text: 4. Involve your teen in creating daily plans. Set goals and rewards together. Let them plan when they do schoolwork and when they can relax!

text: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"
source_text: 2. Transition warnings can also be very helpful. They give your child some time to prepare for the next activity: "In 5 minutes it will be time to pack up the toys before bedtime…"

text: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.
source_text: 3. Regular eating and sleeping times are especially important for babies. Not enough sleep can make your child cranky, irritable, and short tempered.

text: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.
source_text: • Give your child a hug and kiss goodnight before leaving the room.

text: Book-sharing can be a great learning for your child. You can use simple pictures in books, magazines, or newspapers to do lots of things that you and your child can enjoy.
source_text: Book-sharing can be a great learning for your child. You can use simple pictures in books, magazines, or newspapers to do lots of things that you and your child can enjoy.

text: Here's a video to take you through the shared book reading activity!
source_text: Here's a video to take you through the shared book reading activity!

text: Here are some tips for sharing books with your child:
source_text: Here are some tips for sharing books with your child:

text: 1. Follow your child's interest
source_text: 1. Follow your child's interest

text: 2. Use a lifely voice
source_text: 2. Use a lifely voice

text: 3. Pointing and naming
source_text: 3. Pointing and naming

text: 4. Be positive and supportive
source_text: 4. Be positive and supportive

text: 5. Making actions and links
source_text: 5. Making actions and links

text: 6. Talking about feelings
source_text: 6. Talking about feelings

text: 7. Babies and books go well together
source_text: 7. Babies and books go well together

text: 1. Follow your child’s interest
source_text: 1. Follow your child’s interest

text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest
source_text: Talk about what interests your child. When your child shows interest in a picture (pointing, patting, looking), use this as a chance to talk about what has attracted your child’s interest

text: 2. Use a lively voice
source_text: 2. Use a lively voice

text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.
source_text: Speak with a lively or animated voice. This will help to keep the child’s attention on the book.

text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!
source_text: Well done! You have added another tool to your Parenting Toolbox! Sharing books with your child will help them to learn to speak, think and focus better. It will also help them to get along with others better, by helping them understand about feelings. Chat to you later!

text: 3. Pointing and naming
source_text: 3. Pointing and naming

text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).
source_text: Pointing to and naming an object or person in the book will help your child learn new words. Children learn through repetition, so repeat the word and look for other opportunities to use the word (in the book or elsewhere).

text: 4. Be positive and supportive
source_text: 4. Be positive and supportive

text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”
source_text: Always respond positively to whatever your child says about the pictures. For example, if your child points to a red apple and says “Tomato”, you can say “Yes, you’re right, it’s red - it's an apple!”

text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.
source_text: If your child knows a word and can say that word, ask “What’s that?” and give them the opportunity to say the word and point to it.

text: 5. Making actions and links
source_text: 5. Making actions and links

text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.
source_text: Connect things in the book with familiar things in your child’s world. For example, if the baby in the book is wearing shoes, ask your child to point out their own shoes. If someone in the book is waving, you and your child can do the same.

text: 6. Talking about feelings
source_text: 6. Talking about feelings

text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.
source_text: Books are a great way for children to learn more about feelings. You can use your face and voice to help them understand emotion words like happy, sad, angry, or scared. You can use what is happening in the book to talk about your child’s own feelings, and why other people might feel a certain way.

text: 7. Babies and Books!
source_text: 7. Babies and Books!

text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!
source_text: Even very young babies enjoy book-sharing and looking at the pictures together with a parent or caregiver. In fact, regular book-sharing helps their development and learning. And it is okay for them to put the book in their mouth - they are exploring!

text: Here are some examples!
source_text: Here are some examples!

text: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”
source_text: “Look, she is smiling. Why do you think she is smiling? What made you smile today?”

text: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”
source_text: “The monkey is sad because he is all on his own. Can you remember when you were last sad?”

text: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”
source_text: “That tiger looks angry. Why do you think he is angry? Do you remember when I got angry this morning?”

text: You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.
source_text: You can use books and stories to help talk with children about topics related to COVID-19 (such as getting sick, not going to school or work, staying indoors, feeling worried) and help them think about how this makes them feel.

text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.
source_text: We all make mistakes! The more consistent we are with our consequences, the more likely our children will choose to behave positively in the future.

text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!
source_text: This is hard to remember! When you give your child a choice, you teach your child decision making skills. It does not always work, but when it does, it helps avoid having to give a consequence and a difficult situation later!

text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.
source_text: Check to make sure your consequence is fair and reasonable. For example, if your child refuses to help put away their toys, try prohibiting playing with them for an evening instead of threatening to throw them away.

text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!
source_text: When we take a pause before responding, it helps us to calm down and respond better. Next time your child or teen makes you angry, try to take a pause first. Even a few deep breaths can make a big difference!

text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.
source_text: Sometimes our children will react in a negative way when receiving a consequence. If your child is younger than 9 and throws a tantrum, you should ignore your child's behaviour until it is over.  If your child is older, you might need to walk away until they calm down.

text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!
source_text: If you find yourself always having to give consequences to your children for behaving badly, you might need to spend more positive time with them. It will help them feel more loved and secure...and you less stressed!

text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.
source_text: Sharing emotions – especially the difficult ones – sets an important example for your child or teen! It actually makes everyone in the family stronger, because you can understand and support each other better.

text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.
source_text: Starting a new thing is always difficult at first. Give yourselves some time to get used to it, and keep giving the good example by noticing and sharing emotions. Over time, your child or teen will learn to do the same – and they will feel even more loved and cared for.

text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.
source_text: Sharing emotions is about explaining how you are feeling so your child or teen is aware and learns to do the same. You can choose how much detail you want to share about the situation. It’s up to you! You can also choose to answer questions later: “I am feeling angry/stressed now, can you please give me some time? We can talk about this more tonight”.

text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.
source_text: It’s okay to not want to share at that time. Find some time later on when you feel calmer to explain so that everyone can understand.

text: Being specific is not rude or insensitive, it really helps others understand you clearly and prevents confusion in the family. Emotions like anger and stress are part of our lives. All we need to do when we feel angry and stressed is know how to handle it by taking a few deep breaths before responding.

text: Sometimes, our children can have very violent tantrums when they do not get their way, especially if they are used to it. Try to move your child to a place where they will not hurt themselves or others. You may need to firmly hold your child while ignoring their behaviour - but only do this if you can remain calm and  make sure you are not hurting them! Eventually, your child will calm down.

flow_name: PLH - Content - Relax - Take a pause

flow_name: PLH - Content - Relax - Take a pause
text: Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.
source_text: Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Whatever you are feeling, it is okay. Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.

flow_name: PLH - Content - Relax - Take a pause
text: Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths.
source_text: Focus on your breath as it goes in and out. Do this for about 10 breaths.

flow_name: PLH - Content - Relax - Take a pause
text: Now, expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.

text: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.
